Award.AwardTitle: SNM: Roll-to-Roll Manufacturing of High Quality Bucky-tape with Aligned and Crosslinked Carbon Nanotubes Through In-line Sensing and Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) demonstrate amazing properties; however, currently only a fraction of these properties can be transferred into products that can be used by engineers and consumers. To effectively transfer CNTs? properties into useful products requires a method to efficiently align and covalently interconnect the CNTs into tailored architectures at the nanoscale. This project will establish the fundamental understanding and foundation for using CNTs to make thin sheet materials, called Bucky-tapes, which can be rapidly produced in roll form and scaled-up for industrial applications. The proposed method will use a modified die-casting manufacturing process utilizing the self-repelling effects of selected flow media. In-situ ultra-violet (UV) reaction chemistry can covalently interconnect the CNTs rapidly to improve the load transfer and thermal and electronic transport properties of CNT networks. In-line multi-stage stretching of the web could orient the randomly dispersed interconnected CNT networks into specific patterns to provide greater strength and optimized transport properties. In-line Raman spectra monitoring and multistage process models will provide affordable, closed loop quality control and variation reduction methods for a high quality consistent nanomanufacturing process. A prototype will be built to demonstrate the continuous roll-to-roll process for manufacturing strong Bucky-tapes with high electrical and thermal conductivity, and low manufacturing cost.

This project can transform CNT thin films networks from a lab-scale demonstration material into commercially viable products with superior properties potentially surpassing the state-of-the-art carbon fiber material. The continuous Bucky-tapes can lead to new materials applications in aerospace, electronics, energy, medicine, and transportation. For example, continuous Bucky-tape could replace metal shielding of 60 miles of cables in the Boeing 787 and reduce cable weight by 25%. The education and outreach plan will expose especially under-represented students to molecular design, nanomanufacturing process development and quality control, structure-property relationship studies. Application oriented materials-by-design and nanomanufacturing process development will motivate students into nanotechnology, manufacturing and new materials development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) demonstrate amazing properties and offer potential applications for new product development requiring higher strength, electrical and thermal conductivity properties. Free standing and continuous thin film of CNT networks or buckypaper offers a promising method for transferring CNTs into scalable industrial applications. In this project, the joint research team aimed to establish a fundamental understanding and develop new techniques to overcome major scale-up manufacturing challenges for fabricating roll-to-roll CNT buckypaper. The in-line dispersion quality study resulted in a method to quantitatively measure and understand dispersion dynamics and stability for providing high quality suspension. The in-line Raman detection approach provided a critical close-loop feedback for quality control to ensure quality consistency and degree of alignment for the continuous CNT buckypaper production. The proposed generalized wavelet shrinkage and tensor mixed effects models were effective for processing high-dimensional Raman mapping data and are able to quantify quality variation information through statistical analysis. Through integrating optimal continuous sonication dispersion and filtration designs and processing parameters, the team established a roll-to-roll pilot process for manufacturing high quality and continuous CNT buckypaper rolls at widths of 6-inches and 12-inches and 1~20 GSM (gram per square meter) areal density. Several post-process treatments were also explored to improve the mechanical and transport properties for multifunctional applications. The resultant roll-to-roll materials at lengths from a few feet up to 200 feet can provide research communities and industrial collaborators the potential for scale-up applications for nanomaterials.

About 12 undergraduate researchers and 16 graduate students participated the project. Among them, six students were female and four students were African American. The excellent research experiences of the students resulted in numerous awards, scholarships and fellowships, including the NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, Gilbreth Memorial Fellowship, McKnight Doctoral Fellowship and Cytec Solvay Group Engineered Materials Doctoral Fellowship for Advanced Composite Studies, IEEE and INFORM best papers and SAMPE best student research awards. Many graduates directly moved into major manufacturing industries and academia upon graduation. The scientific and engineering concepts, as well as lab demonstrations of the scale-up manufacturing process and materials, are now used in both undergraduate and graduate classes at FSU, including Engineering and Manufacturing Processes II and Composite Engineering classes, as well as Senior Design Projects. The research methodology and results are major components in the graduate level course Advanced Manufacturing in the School of Industrial & Systems Engineering at Georgia Tech. This course have been taken by many MS and PhD students at GT-ISYE. The project provided an excellent demonstration site to attract potential STEM students and show the transition from fundamental nanomaterial research to scale-up manufacturing for new product development. K-12 students were introduced to nanotechnology and engineering through lab tours and open-houses. The pilot manufacturing setup and continuous CNT buckypaper samples were shown to numerous government and industrial visitors on a weekly bases. The research results were also disseminated through invited seminars, about 17 journal publications, and 12 conference papers. The effort also leads to multiple patent applications.

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2018
Modified by: Zhiyong Liang

Free standing and continuous thin film of CNT networks or buckypaper offers a promising method for transferring CNTs into scalable industrial applications. The in-line Raman detection approach provided a critical close-loop feedback for quality control to ensure quality consistency and degree of alignment for the continuous CNT buckypaper production. The proposed generalized wavelet shrinkage and tensor mixed effects models were effective for processing high-dimensional Raman mapping data and are able to quantify quality variation information through statistical analysis. Through integrating optimal continuous sonication dispersion and filtration designs and processing parameters, the team established a roll-to-roll pilot process for manufacturing high quality and continuous CNT buckypaper rolls at widths of 6-inches and 12-inches and 1~20 GSM (gram per square meter) areal density. Several post-process treatments were also explored to improve the mechanical and transport properties for multifunctional applications. The resultant roll-to-roll materials at lengths from a few feet up to 200 feet can provide research communities and industrial collaborators the potential for scale-up applications for nanomaterials. About 12 undergraduate researchers and 16 graduate students participated the project. Among them, six students were female and four students were African American. The scientific and engineering concepts, as well as lab demonstrations of the scale-up manufacturing process and materials, are now used in both undergraduate and graduate classes at FSU, including Engineering and Manufacturing Processes II and Composite Engineering classes, as well as Senior Design Projects.
